t: Proverbs 21
A*pn king’s heart is like channeled water in the Lord’s*s hand: He*ln directs it wherever he chooses.
All*pn a person’s ways seem right to him, but*ln the Lord*s weighs hearts.
Doing*pn what is righteous and just is*ln more acceptable to the Lord*s than sacrifice.
The*pn lamp that guides the wicked — haughty*ln eyes and an arrogant heart- is sin.
The*pn plans of the diligent certainly lead to profit, but*ln anyone who is reckless certainly becomes poor.
Making*pn a fortune through a lying tongue is*ln a vanishing mist, a pursuit of death.
The*pn violence of the wicked sweeps them away because*ln they refuse to act justly.
A*pn guilty one’s conduct is crooked, but*ln the behavior of the innocent is upright.
Better*pn to live on the corner of a roof than*ln to share a house with a nagging wife.
A*pn wicked person desires evil; he*ln has no consideration for his neighbor.
When*pn a mocker is punished, the*ln inexperienced become wiser; when*ln one teaches a wise man, he*ln acquires knowledge.
The*pn Righteous One considers the house of the wicked; he*ln brings the wicked to ruin.
The*pn one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will*ln himself also call out and not be answered.
A*pn secret gift soothes anger, and*ln a covert bribe, fierce rage.
Justice*pn executed is a joy to the righteous but*ln a terror to evildoers.
The*pn person who strays from the way of prudence will*ln come to rest in the assembly of the departed spirits.
The*pn one who loves pleasure will become poor; whoever*ln loves wine and oil will not get rich.
The*pn wicked are a ransom for the righteous, and*ln the treacherous, for the upright.
Better*pn to live in a wilderness than*ln with a nagging and hot-tempered wife.
Precious*pn treasure and oil are in the dwelling of a wise person, but*ln a fool consumes them.
The*pn one who pursues righteousness and faithful love will*ln find life, righteousness, and honor.
A*pn wise person went up against a city of warriors and*ln brought down its secure fortress.
The*pn one who guards his mouth and tongue keeps*ln himself out of trouble.
The*pn arrogant and proud person, named “Mocker,” acts*ln with excessive arrogance.
A*pn slacker’s craving will kill him because*ln his hands refuse to work.
He*ln is filled with craving all day long, but*ln the righteous give and don’t hold back.
The*pn sacrifice of a wicked person is detestable — how*ln much more so when*ln he brings it with ulterior motives!
A*pn lying witness will perish, but*ln the one who listens will speak successfully.
A*pn wicked person puts on a bold face, but*ln the upright one considers his way.
No*pn wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel will*ln prevail against the Lord.*s
A*pn horse is prepared for the day of battle, but*ln victory comes from the Lord.*s
